metadata.case_name: Messrs. Newton Chikli Collieries Limited v. Income Tax Authorities

facts.text: Messrs. Newton Chikli Collieries Limited, registered under Indian Companies Act, carried on business of raising coal from Newton Chikli Collieries.
Controlling interest in assessee company with Europeans till January 1946; Mrs. Jackson managing director till January 1946; K.C. Shah became managing director thereafter.
For assessment year 1949-50 (account year ending December 31, 1948), assessee assessed to income-tax and business profits tax.
Income-tax Officer added back Rs. 50,000 to expenses under wages and salaries (claimed Rs. 12,18,409 vs. Rs. 8,04,766 previous year) on ground of inflation.
Defects noticed in acquittance rolls and wages record.
Tribunal opined original addition of Rs. 50,000 sufficient; no justification for further Rs. 2.5 lakhs.
Assessee moved Tribunal u/s 66(1) Income-tax Act 1922 and s.19 Business Profits Tax Act 1947 for reference; rejected as finding of fact.
High Court of Nagpur u/s 66(2) directed Tribunal to state case on three questions.
High Court answered first two questions against assessee; third consequently against assessee, dated February 24, 1955.
Supreme Court granted special leave; present appeal filed.
Assessee explained increase in wages by Government resolution October 10, 1947; increased cost of cutting coal; increase in workmen; cost of explosives, kerosene etc. borne by company.
ITO asked for comparative statement salaries department-wise 1939-1948; assessee failed, filed increased rates statement; no evidence of increases.
Acquittance rolls: payments acknowledged by others; literate persons thumb impressions; shift work explanation; some no acknowledgments (inadvertence).

legal_issues.text: Whether there was any material before the Tribunal for the finding that the wages had been inflated?
Is there any material on record supporting the estimate of Rs. 50,000?
Whether the disallowance of Rs. 50,000 was a valid deduction from expenditure under section 10 of the Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: No materials from which inference of inflation in wages and salaries could be drawn.
Tribunal accepted explanations for increase; original addition sufficient without ground for inflation.
No opportunity given to explain defects in acquittance rolls; addition based on no material, violation of section 23(3).

court_reasoning.text: There was material: failure to produce comparative statement; defects in acquittance rolls (wrong acknowledgments, thumb marks, no acknowledgments); explanations not accepted but material exists; inflation finding is question of fact.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Non-acceptance of explanations does not convert fact question to law.

court_reasoning.text: No violation of s.23(3): assessee produced some materials considered; not required opportunity for every reason; Tribunal accepted some explanations but still found inflation warranting Rs.50,000 addition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: ITO and appellate authorities considered materials produced.

court_reasoning.text: High Court rightly answered questions against assessee.

holdings.text: Material existed for Tribunal's finding of wage inflation; estimate of Rs.50,000 supported; disallowance valid u/s 10.
No violation of principles of natural justice u/s 23(3).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs allowability of wages deduction, opportunity to assessee, reference to High Court.

statutes_cited.name: Business Profits Tax Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference procedure similar to IT Act.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court judgment answering questions against assessee, confirming addition of Rs.50,000 for inflated wages; appeal lacks substance.

key_quotes.text: For such defects as were noticed in the keeping of acquittance rolls and wages record, we are of the opinion that the original addition of Rs. 50,000... was quite sufficient.
key_quotes.speaker: tribunal
key_quotes.significance: Tribunal's view on sufficiency of addition.

key_quotes.text: The non-acceptance of the explanations given by the assessee company converts the question of the inflation of wages... into a question of law.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court rejects appellant's contention on question of law vs fact.

key_quotes.text: Both points urged on behalf of the appellant are without substance and our considered conclusion is that the High Court rightly answered the questions referred to it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
